journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Physical and mechanical characterization of jute reinforced soy composites

article-meta.aff: 1Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
2Department of Biotechnology, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India

author-notes.corresp: Basudam Adhikari, Materials Science Centre, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, WB 721302, India. Email: ba@matsc.iitkgp.ernet.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Jute fiber and soymilk extracted from soy seed were selected as ecofriendly and fully biodegradable components for making rigid and strong composite as a replacement of composites made from synthetic components. Rigid composites were prepared using non-woven jute fabric (felt) as reinforcing component and soymilk as matrix resin and properties of the composite specimens were characterized. Jute fiber in the non-woven jute fabric was modified by treating with different concentrations of sodium hydroxide for various time periods before composite fabrication. Significant increase in tensile strength (upto 42%) of jute fibers in the felt was achieved by 2 h, 2% alkali treatment. Both raw and alkali-treated jute felts were used for preparing composites with soy milk as resin using furfuraldehyde as cross linking agent. Different composites were fabricated by varying the quantity of jute felt, crosslinking agent and hot compression time and the process parameters were optimized. Mechanical properties of alkali-treated jute felt composites exhibited better tensile properties than those of raw jute felt composites. These biodegradable jute soy composites with comparable mechanical properties can potentially serve as cost-effective eco-friendly alternative to synthetic polymer-based non-biodegradable fiber composites in automobile, furniture and packaging industries.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, there has been growing interest in exploring the field of natural fiber reinforced composites to deal with the ecological concerns caused by the use of non-biodegradable petroleum-based polymers. Renewability, low cost, biodegradability, low energy consumption, adequate specific properties, abundant availability of natural fibers bring about their utilization in diversified applications. Natural fibers like jute, ramie, sisal, banana, hemp, kenaf have been successfully exploited for the use of natural fiber reinforced composites.1

Natural fiber reinforced composites have good mechanical properties and low specific mass.2 However, hydrophilic character of natural fibers is the primary drawback leading to inadequate adhesion with the hydrophobic polymer matrices. Modification of fiber surface is, therefore, essential for better interfacial bonding between reinforcing fiber and polymer matrix. Surface modifications can be achieved by alkali treatment, cyanoethylation, silane treatment, esterification, acetylation, grafting, etc. based on polymeric matrix.3 Mercerization, surface modification of fiber achieved by alkali treatment, is a familiar method followed for better resin wettability.2,3

Mwaikambo et al.3 reported the partial removal of hemicellulose and lignin from natural fibers after alkali treatment which was reaffirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis. Improvement in tensile properties of the jute fiber by alkali treatment has been extensively studied. Ray et al.4 have modified jute fiber surface by alkali treatment which increased the fiber specific properties. Patel et al.5 used alkali-treated jute for better resin wettability and improved mechanical properties. Mukharjee et al.6 reported the removal of hemicellulose, after alkali treatment of jute fibers. They suggested that the inter-fibrillar region is likely to be less dense and less rigid after exposure to alkali for which fibrils are more capable of rearranging themselves along the direction of tensile deformation. Wang et al.7 studied the changes in composition and properties of jute fiber after alkali treatment. It was suggested that alkali treatment leads to removal of non-crystalline structural components leading to closer packing of cellulose chains and improved mechanical properties.8 Coir, sisal and other natural fibers were alkali-treated to prepare composites with improved resin wettability and mechanical properties.3,9 Alkali treatment of fiber also improves adhesion with resin by increasing the free hydroxyl groups on the fiber surface.10 Alkali treatment also increases fibrils splitting for better interfacial bonding between resin and fiber interface.11,12

Researchers have reported about jute reinforced composites based on synthetic matrices like polypropylene, polyethylene,13 and vinyl ester.14 These composites show good tensile strength but are not biodegradable. Amid variety of biodegradable matrices available from renewable resources, soy protein based resins have received significant interest. People have developed green composites using biodegradable resins like soy protein isolate (SPI),15 Biopol,16 and starch17 with natural fibers. Soy resin is, therefore, considered to be a prospective substitute to petroleum based resins due to eco-friendliness, easy handling, and biodegradability.18 Aldehydes like formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, glyoxal, furfuraldehyde were used as crosslinking agents to improve the properties of soy resins.19 Commercially available soy resins in the form of SPI, soy protein concentrate (SPC), and soy flour involve extra processing of soy seeds. In order to avoid expensive method of SPI and SPC preparation direct use of soymilk, extracted from water soaked soy seed, as matrix resin in jute composite fabrication has been reported earlier.20 Other than mechanical properties and biodegradability of the composites, the effects of fiber treatment, variation of fiber loading, and composite fabrication parameters were not reported. In the present communication we report the soymilk alkali-treated jute felt composite fabrication using furfuraldehyde as crosslinking agent with subsequent characterization. Effect of alkali treatment on fiber and composite properties were evaluated. Composites were fabricated by varying fiber loading, hot compression time, amount of crosslinking agent to optimize the composite fabrication parameters. Effects of moisture and water absorption on mechanical properties of these composites were also evaluated and discussed for appropriate applications.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Jute non-woven felts were obtained from Gloster Jute Mills Limited, West Bengal, India. Sodium hydroxide, Furfuraldehyde, Ammonium hydroxide, Acetic acid, Sodium chloride, Potassium nitrate (Merck, India) and soy beans were obtained from local market.

sec.title: Modification of jute felt
sec.p: Jute felts were washed with distilled water and dried in oven at 60℃ till constant weight was obtained. These jute felts were dipped in different concentrations (1%, 2%, 3%, 4%, and 5%) of sodium hydroxide solution for different time periods (0.5, 1, 2, and 3 h) at ambient temperature (30 ± 2℃) maintaining the liquor to jute ratio at 20:1. Jute felts were neutralized with 0.01 M dilute acetic acid and washed thoroughly with distilled water. These treated jute felts were oven dried at 60℃ till constant weight was obtained. Alkali-treated jute felts were characterized and used for composite fabrication.

sec.title: Composite fabrication using raw and alkali-treated jute felts
sec.p: Soymilk was extracted from water-soaked soybean by crushing, squeezing, and filtering. Soymilk was made ammonical to resist bacterial attack and stored below 10℃.20 A water-based liquid soy resin compound was prepared by mixing soymilk with different amounts of furfuraldehyde (1%, 3%, 5%, 7%, 9%, 11% w/w soy resin) and stirred for 20 min. For optimization of crosslinking agent, composites were fabricated with 60% jute and 40% resin varying the furfuraldehyde content. To check the effect of fiber loading, different weight percentages (40, 50, 60, 70 wt%) of jute was used for composite fabrication using optimum amount of furfuraldehyde. Raw jute felts and alkali-treated jute felts were used for preparing raw jute felt reinforced soy composite (RJC) and alkali-treated jute reinforced soy composite (AJC), respectively. Jute felts were soaked in compounded soy resin for 15 min and then partially dried in an oven at 70℃. These partially dried resin impregnated jute felts were compressed in hydraulic press at 130℃, 12 ton ram pressure varying the compression time to fabricate composites. Composites prepared were of the dimension (10 × 10 × 0.14 cm3).

sec.title: Jute felt characterization after alkali treatment
sec.p: Weights of jute felts before and after alkali treatment were measured. The percentage loss in weight was calculated using the following equation (1)Weight loss (%)=100×(Wi-Wf)Wi where Wi is the dry weight of washed and dried fiber before alkali treatment, Wf is the dry weight of washed and dried fiber after alkali treatment. Chemical composition of jute fibers before and after alkali treatment was determined according to the standard procedures as published elsewhere.21

Tensile strength of raw and alkali-treated jute fibres were measured according to ASTM D-3822 by tensile testing instrument (HOUNSFIELD H10KS UTM) at a grip separation speed of 2 mm/min. Twenty fibers collected from untreated and alkali-treated jute felts were tested. The results were analysed by two parameter weibull distribution method.

For morphological analysis powders of raw and alkali-treated jute fibers were taken, coated with gold by plasma sputtering apparatus and examined using TESCAN VEGA LSV scanning electron microscope (SEM).

FTIR characterization of raw and alkali-treated jute fibers were performed using a Thermo Nicolet, Nexus 870 IR spectrometer. The spectrum was recorded from 400 cm−1 to 4000 cm−1. Dried jute powder and KBr were thoroughly ground in dry atmosphere and pelletized for recording FTIR spectrum.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: Tensile strength, tensile modulus and elongation at break of RJC and AJC composites were measured by tensile testing instrument (HOUNSFIELD H10KS UTM) at a grip separation speed of 5 mm/min and 50 mm gage length according to ASTM D-638. Flexural properties of composites were measured according to ASTM D-790 by above mentioned instrument with a grip separation speed of 2 mm/min. The specimens for flexural testing were 2 in. long × 1/2 in. wide, tested flatwise 1-in. support span. Five different specimens of each sample were analysed and average value is reported.

sec.title: Moisture and water absorption
sec.p: Equilibrium moisture content of RJC and AJC composites was measured at room temperature (30 ± 1℃) by exposing the samples to 75%, 85% and 90% relative humidity (RH) in a closed chamber till constant weight. In the closed chamber, 75% RH was created by using saturated aqueous solution of sodium chloride, 85% RH by saturated aqueous solution of potassium chloride, and 90% RH using saturated aqueous solution of potassium nitrate. For measuring moisture absorption, cured composite samples were placed in a humid chamber after taking the initial dry weight (Wi). After the stipulated time these specimens were taken out and weighed (Wf). The composites were kept in the humid chamber till the specimens obtained constant weight. The moisture absorption was calculated using the following equation (2)Absorption (%)=100×(Wf-Wi)Wi Similarly, the water absorption of composite samples was determined according to ASTM D-570 using the equation (2). The composite specimens were immersed in distilled water at room temperature (30 ± 1℃) and weight was measured after 24 h (Wf). Water absorption of RJC and AJC in boiling water was determined by immersing the composite specimens in boiling water for 2 h.

sec.title: Change of jute properties after alkali treatment
sec.p:
The weight loss of jute felts treated with different concentrations of alkali for various time periods of immersion were measured and the results are shown in Figure 1. It was observed that the weight loss of jute fiber increased with the increase of alkali concentration and immersion time. The observed weight loss is due to the removal of hemicellulose and other alkali-soluble components present in jute previously. The inter-linkage of fibrils bound by pectin in raw jute is ruptured by alkali treatment.7 Jute consists of cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, pectin and some amount of wax. Saha et al.21 have studied the composition and weight loss of jute after alkali treatment and reported that cellulose remains unaffected while hemicellulose is partially eliminated. Estimation of hemicellulose, cellulose, and lignin of jute fiber before and after alkali treatment was done using acidic and neutral detergent solutions22 and the results are in agreement with available literature. Figure 1.
Weight loss of jute fiber after alkali treatment.

sec.title: Tensile strength of raw and alkali-treated jute felt
sec.p:
Tensile properties of natural fibers show wide scattering and hence a statistical approach is necessary. Scattered data consistently fits two parameter Weibull distribution of the form shown in the following equation (3)S(σ)=exp[-(σσ0)m] where σ is the tensile modulus of fiber collected from jute felt, S(σ) is the probability that the tensile strength of fiber is less than σ.23 Weibull plot of 2% 2 h alkali-treated jute is given in Figure 2(a). Tensile modulus of alkali-treated jute fibers obtained from Weibull plot are shown in Figure 2(b). Raw jute fiber showed tensile modulus of 8 GPa. With increase in treatment time for all concentration of alkali, tensile modulus enhanced to certain extent (upto 2 h), and then gradually decreased with further increase in alkali concentration. This can be attributed to the loss of cementitious components like hemicellulose and pectin present in jute. Lower concentration of alkali (1–2%) partially removes hemicellulose and pectin from the inter fibrillar region. This helps in ordered arrangement of fibrils within the fiber due to which the tensile properties are improved. Alkali treatment defibrillates the fiber, also increasing the fiber aspect ratio. Jute fiber treated with 2% alkali for 2 h showed maximum tensile strength of 13 GPa and these treated fibers were used in composite fabrication. Jute fibers treated with higher alkali concentration resulted in stiffness and brittleness, thereby decreasing the fiber tensile strength. Figure 2.
(a) Weibull linear fit of 2% 2 h alkali treatment, (b) Effect of alkali concentration and exposure time on tensile modulus of jute fiber.

sec.title: SEM analysis of jute felt
sec.p:
Surface morphology of jute before and after 2%, 2 h alkali treatment is shown in Figure 3. In raw jute fiber (Figure 3(a)), compact structure of fiber can be observed due to the binding of fibrils by pectin and hemicellulose. After alkali treatment, the raw jute fibers were split into fibrils and fiber surface roughness increased. Partial exclusion of different components like hemi-cellulose, other carbohydrates, lignin, etc., from jute surface develops surface roughness. Increase in surface area can be observed by comparing SEM pictures of raw jute and alkali-treated jute fiber (Figure 3(a) and (b)). Increase in surface area facilitates resin impregnation thereby increasing the strength of the composites. Figure 3.
SEM photomicrographs (a) raw jute and (b) 2 h 2% alkali treated jute fiber.

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopic analysis
sec.p:
Infrared spectra of raw jute and 2%, 2 h alkali-treated jute fiber are given in Figure 4. For raw jute and alkali-treated jute fibers, a characteristic peak of OH group is observed at around 3200–3500 cm−1 which becomes less intense after alkali treatment, due to breaking of inter molecular hydrogen bonding. Intensity of peak at 1500–1620 cm−1 is reduced after alkali treatment due to breaking of hydrogen bonding between cellulose and lignin. The –OH stretching peak at 3300 cm−1, –CH stretching peak at 2930 cm−1, and the –C–O–C– stretching peaks at 1060 cm−1 and 1110 cm−1 are characteristic peaks of cellulose as listed in Table 1. These characteristics peaks are present in spectra of both raw and alkali-treated jute indicating that cellulose remains unaffected. However, intensity of –CH stretching vibration of hemicellulose at 2930 cm−1 decreases after alkali treatment indicating removal of hemicellulose. The peak observed at 848 cm−1 indicates the presence of the β-glycosidic linkages between the monosaccharides. This bond disappears in treated fiber as the monosaccharides are removed by alkali. In 2%, 2 h alkali-treated jute fibers, ester linkage existing between the hemicellulose and lignin is cleaved and thus peak at 1750 cm−1 diminishes in alkali-treated jute indicating removal of hemicellulose.3,21 Figure 4.
FTIR spectra of (a) raw jute fiber, and (b) 2%, 2 h alkali treated jute fiber.
Table 1.
Assignments of infrared bands.
Frequency (cm−1) Vibration
840 β-glycosidic linkages
1160 –C–O–C– bonds in cellulose
1496 Aromatic skeletal vibration in lignin
1728 C = O stretching of acetyl groups
2960–2860 C–H stretching in methyl and methylene of cellulose and hemicellulose
3600–3000 Hydrogen-bonded OH stretching

sec.title: Mechanical properties of composites
sec.p: Mechanical properties of jute composites were measured to meet the requirements for end application.

sec.title: Effects of furfuraldehyde as curing agent on the mechanical properties of composites
sec.p:
Effects of furfuraldehyde as crosslinking agent in composite on tensile and flexural properties are shown in Figures 5 and 6, respectively. Furfuraldehyde binds with amino groups present at terminal and side chain of soy protein of soymilk to improve composite strength.19 It was found that tensile strength of composites increased with increase in furfuraldehyde content from 1% to 7%. Mechanical properties of composites improved due to effective crosslinking of the matrix and increase in resin crosslink density. However, further increase in furfuraldehyde concentration does not increase tensile properties of composites as there are not enough sites in soy protein for crosslinking. Hence 7% of furfuraldehyde is considered as optimum. Alkali treatment of jute fibers leaves cellulosic hydroxyl groups active for better resin wetting as compared to that of raw jute fiber. It is observed that the alkali-treated jute composite has higher tensile strength of 35 MPa and tensile modulus of 1546 MPa than that of raw jute reinforced composite (31 MPa and 980 MPa, respectively) as illustrated in Figure 5. Flexural properties of both RJC and AJC composites are shown in Figure 6. Alkali-treated jute composites showed nearly 32% improvement in flexural properties over raw jute composites. Ordered arrangement within jute after alkali treatment, increases the stiffness of composite. Maximum mechanical properties are obtained for 7% of furfuraldehyde for both raw jute and alkali-treated jute-based composites. Figure 5.
Effect of furfuraldehyde content on tensile properties of raw and alkali treated jute composites.
Figure 6.
Flexural properties of raw and alkali treated jute composites.

sec.title: Effect of fiber loading on mechanical properties of jute-soy composites
sec.p:
Mechanical properties of composites were predicted using Cox–Krenchel theory.23 Cox–Krenchel model of modified rule of mixtures is given by (5)Ec=η0ηLEfVf+Em(1-Vf) where Ec, Ef, and Em are tensile moduli of composite, fiber, and resin, respectively; Vf is the fiber volume fraction; ηL is the fiber length correlation factor, where ηL ≈ 1 for fiber lengths ≥10 mm, while, η0 is Krenchel fiber orientation factor for non-unidirectional reinforcement, given by (6)η0=∑nancos4φn where an is the fraction of fibers with orientation angle φn with respect to the loading axis. In three dimensional random fibre orientations, the fiber orientation factor yields the value of 1/5. Figure 7 shows Young’s modulus of raw and alkali-treated jute composites along with Krenchel model predictions. In the model, the modulus of raw and alkali-treated jute fibers were considered to be 8 GPa and 13 GPa respectively from Weibull two-parameter analyses. Modulus of soy resin with 7% furfuraldehyde was evaluated to be 0.18 GPa. A rather close agreement is found between the model and the experimental data as illustrated in Figure 7. Discrepancies can be attributed to several reasons including shrinkage of resin during curing, alignment of fibers, presence of voids, thermal degradation. A significant amount of water is used for resin preparation. During curing, the water is dried and resin shrinks. The fibers undergo tension during hot compression and lose their alignment resulting in less modulus. It was found that with the increase in fiber content (40% to 60%) both tensile and flexural strengths of composites (raw and alkali-treated jute) were increased. Mechanical properties of alkali-treated jute composites are better than that of raw jute composite by about 38%. It is found that 60% fiber loading gives maximum strength in both raw and alkali-treated jute composites due to adequate wetting of fiber surface by 40% soy resin. Further increase in fiber loading leads to delamination of composite specimens at lower load due to insufficient matrix for binding. Hence to optimize compression time, 60% fiber loaded composites (both raw and alkali-treated jute) were examined. Figure 7.
Effect of fiber loading on mechanical properties of raw and alkali treated jute composites. The solid line represents krenchel prediction for (a) raw and (b) alkali treated jute composites, respectively while the dotted line represents the experimental data.

sec.title: Effect of hot compression time on mechanical properties of soy-jute composites
sec.p:
Hot compression time provides adequate energy for matrix to flow and bind the jute fibers. Mechanical strength of raw and alkali-treated jute composites prepared at different compression times is shown in Figure 8. Shorter time gives insufficient energy for good adhesion of soy resin on jute surface and thus resulting in poorer mechanical properties. Increasing compression time assists enhanced binding between matrix and fibers thereby improving mechanical strength of composites. It is observed that 5–15 min of compression time, mechanical properties of composites were increased considerably. However, 20 min compression could not enhance the mechanical strength significantly as shown in Figure 8. Carbohydrates and protein entities present in the resin matrix began to char when compression time exceeded 20 min. Figure 8.
Effect of hot compression time on mechanical properties of raw and alkali treated jute composites.

Process parameters can be varied during composite fabrication to obtain required composite properties. Composites were prepared using 60% jute fiber loading and 40% soy resin with 7% of furfuraldehyde and compressed at 130℃ under 12 ton ram pressure for 15 min.

sec.title: Water and moisture absorption of soy-jute composites
sec.p:
Being hydrophilic in nature, jute fiber takes up moisture from the surroundings and the fiber molecules are pushed apart from each other by means of swelling. This alters the dimension of fiber and in turn causes the change in dimension of the composites. To assess the absorption study with dimensional stability, the prepared composites were subjected to 75% and 90% RH, and the results are shown in Table 2. In both the humid conditions, it is found that the alkali-treated composite acquires less moisture than that of raw jute composite. Table 2.
Water and moisture absorptions of untreated and alkali-treated jute and jute composites.
Samples Water absorption (%) Moisture absorption (%)
24 h, room temp. 2 h, boiling water 75% RH 85% RH 90% RH
Raw jute 133 140 7.22 7.86 8.24
Alkali-treated jute 118 123 5.88 6.24 6.78
Raw jute composite 67 70 5.12 5.37 5.88
Alkali jute composite 55 62 4.12 4.38 4.52

Raw jute composites absorbed 70% and 67% water after immersing in boiling water for 2 h and in water at room temperature for 24 h, respectively. Alkali-treated jute composites are more hydrophobic than the raw jute composite as the former absorbs only 62% water after immersing in boiling water for 2 h. Reduction in hydrophilic nature of alkali jute composites is due to better packing or resin on jute surface, resisting the water penetration. This clearly shows that with the alkali treatment of fiber, water and moisture absorptions of composites decrease because of increase in hydrophobic nature of jute fibers after alkali treatment.7,8

sec.title: Effect of water and moisture absorption on mechanical properties
sec.p:
In order to evaluate effect of water absorption on mechanical properties, composites were tested after immersing in water for 24 h at room temperature and 2 h in boiling water. The main disadvantage of natural fiber composites is water absorption.24 Hydrophilic nature of these natural fibers results in low mechanical properties and dimensional stability of composites. The main reason for water absorption is hydrogen bonding with the cellulosic –OH groups.25 Figure 9 shows loss in strength of composites after water absorption. It was observed that the tensile strength of these composites reduced by up to 35% when immersed in boiling water for 2 h. Untreated jute composites showed maximum loss in strength when immersed in boiling water. Jute fibers absorb water and swell, loosening the bonding with the resin matrix. It was also observed that the composites were slightly delaminated when immersed in boiling water for prolonged time. However, effect of moisture on these composites was observed to be minor. Figure 10 shows the mechanical strengths of reference composite and composites after exposure to moisture at 75% and 90% RH for 10 days. It was observed that the composite strength did not vary much after moisture absorption. Both untreated and alkali-treated composites showed no dimensional deformity after exposure to high humidity. It was observed that the composites are durable and sustainable in humid atmosphere but not stable when in direct contact with water. Figure 9.
Loss in strength after water absorption.
Figure 10.
Strength of reference composite, composites after exposure to 75% and 90% RH for 10 days.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Surface modification of jute fiber was achieved by different concentrations alkali treatment for different time periods. Tensile properties of 2 h, 2% alkali-treated jute fiber showed maximum improvement by up to 62% and was used for fabricating composites. Both raw jute and alkali-treated jute reinforced composites were fabricated and their mechanical and water absorption properties were evaluated. Mechanical properties of composites were predicted using Krenchel model of modified rule of mixtures. It was observed that the alkali-treated jute composites showed better mechanical properties and resistance to water absorption than untreated jute composites due to better fiber matrix bonding. Effect of moisture on the mechanical properties of the composites was studied and found that both alkali and raw jute composites were durable in high humid environment. Composite developed using 60% jute loading and 40% soy resin compounded with 7% furfuraldehyde, and compressed at 130℃ under 12 ton ram pressure for 15 min showed maximum mechanical strength. Fabricated composites were expected to be eco-friendly as the raw materials used were from agro based resources. Unlike plastic materials, these composites can be appreciated for adapting green technology. Applications of these composites cover automobile industry, furniture segment, railway sector, packaging, etc. to replace conventional plastic composites.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: We gratefully acknowledge the financial support provided by the National Jute Board (NJB) (formerly JMDC), Kolkata, Government of India during the tenure of this work.
